user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_strx_to_uint32_:
```c
size_t
MHD_strx_to_uint32_ (const char *str,
                     uint32_t *out_val)
{
  const char *const start = str;
  uint32_t res;
  int digit;

  if (! str || ! out_val)
    return 0;

  res = 0;
  digit = toxdigitvalue (*str);
  while (digit >= 0)
  {
    if ( (res < (UINT32_MAX / 16)) ||
         ((res == (UINT32_MAX / 16)) &&
          ( (uint32_t) digit <= (UINT32_MAX % 16)) ) )
    {
      res *= 16;
      res += (unsigned int) digit;
    }
    else
      return 0;
    str++;
    digit = toxdigitvalue (*str);
  }

  if (str - start > 0)
    *out_val = res;
  return (size_t) (str - start);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No pointer in the provided code appears to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13. Rationale:
- The input string parameter is declared as const char *str, so the pointed-to type is const-qualified and is not modified through the pointer. A local alias is declared as const char *const start, further enforcing constness.
- The only non-const pointer parameter is uint32_t *out_val; this pointer is used to store the computed result (*out_val = res), so the pointed-to object must be modifiable and cannot be const-qualified.
- There are no other pointer variables or pointer-to-object usages in the function that could be further const-qualified.
Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for possible addition of const qualification under Rule 8.13.
